Microplastics (MPs) are an environmental growing concern, with an annual input to the environment of 11 million tons (Boucher and Friot, 2017). Agriculture fields receiving sludge from sewage treatment plants as fertilizers constitute one of the largest inputs of MPs to the environment (63000-430000 t of MPs per year; (Nizzetto et al., 2016). Only in Europe, wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) produce 13 million tons of dry weight sludge per year and approximately 99% of MPs can be retained in the sludge (Magnusson and Norén, 2014). 80% of this sludge is used in agriculture (Mahon et al., 2017). Despite the importance of quantifying the concentrations of MPs in sludge (de Souza et al., 2018;Corradini et al., 2019), to date, there is no standardized protocol for their extraction and quantification (Rocha-Santos and Duarte, 2015;Rochman et al., 2017).Microplastics (MPs) are an environmental growing concern, with an annual input to the environment of 11 million tons (Boucher and Friot, 2017). Agriculture fields receiving sludge from sewage treatment plants as fertilizers constitute one of the largest inputs of MPs to the environment (63000-430000 t of MPs per year; (Nizzetto et al., 2016). Only in Europe, wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) produce 13 million tons of dry weight sludge per year and approximately 99% of MPs can be retained in the sludge (Magnusson and Norén, 2014). 80% of this sludge is used in agriculture (Mahon et al., 2017). Despite the importance of quantifying the concentrations of MPs in sludge (de Souza et al., 2018;Corradini et al., 2019), to date, there is no standardized protocol for their extraction and quantification (Rocha-Santos and Duarte, 2015;Rochman et al., 2017).

Different methodologies have been proposed for the extraction of MPs from sludge samples, generally using oxidizing agents and acids to remove part of the organic matter and a density separation of the MPs by means of saline solutions (Lusher et al., 2017;Sujathan et al., 2017;Hurley et al., 2018;Lares et al., 2018;Li et al., 2018). However, one of the drawbacks of using high concentrations of these agents to remove organic matter is the possible degradation of some polymers, (Avio et al., 2015), difficulting their identification by using Raman and FT-IR spectroscopy (Lares et al., 2018).Different methodologies have been proposed for the extraction of MPs from sludge samples, generally using oxidizing agents and acids to remove part of the organic matter and a density separation of the MPs by means of saline solutions (Lusher et al., 2017;Sujathan et al., 2017;Hurley et al., 2018;Lares et al., 2018;Li et al., 2018). However, one of the drawbacks of using high concentrations of these agents to remove organic matter is the possible degradation of some polymers, (Avio et al., 2015), difficulting their identification by using Raman and FT-IR spectroscopy (Lares et al., 2018).

Additionally, estimates of MPs concentrations must be accompanied by a recovery test of the most abundant types of MPs comprising different sizes. Previous studies quantifying MPs in sludge or in soil samples have generally performed partial recovery tests only using one (Mahon et al., 2017;Sujathan et al., 2017;Li et al., 2018) or two shapes of MPs (Hurley et al., 2018;Corradini et al., 2019) and in some cases a recovery test was not applied (Lusher et al., 2017;van den Berg et al., 2020). Nevertheless, J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f recovery tests are key in assessing the effectiveness of the extraction methods, necessary to design standardized procedures that can precisely estimate MPs concentrations in sewage sludge.Additionally, estimates of MPs concentrations must be accompanied by a recovery test of the most abundant types of MPs comprising different sizes. Previous studies quantifying MPs in sludge or in soil samples have generally performed partial recovery tests only using one (Mahon et al., 2017;Sujathan et al., 2017;Li et al., 2018) or two shapes of MPs (Hurley et al., 2018;Corradini et al., 2019) and in some cases a recovery test was not applied (Lusher et al., 2017;van den Berg et al., 2020). Nevertheless, J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f recovery tests are key in assessing the effectiveness of the extraction methods, necessary to design standardized procedures that can precisely estimate MPs concentrations in sewage sludge.

MPs are expected to alter the biophysical properties of the soil, in terms of water retention capacity, bulk density, microbial activity and formation of aggregates, which could lead to an alteration in the water cycle in the soil (de Souza Machado et al., 2018;Wan et al., 2019). However, the effect that MPs accumulation in the soil will generate on the vegetation has been scarcely studied. MPs present in sludge from WWTPs used in agriculture can remain in soil for a long-time affecting the vegetative growth (van den Berg et al., 2020). In this sense, it has been reported that MPs can induce changes in both aerial and below-ground parts during vegetative growth in the wheat plant (Qi et al., 2018) while reducing the germination rate and root growth of Lepidium sativum as the concentration of MPs to which plants were exposed increased (Bosker et al., 2019).MPs are expected to alter the biophysical properties of the soil, in terms of water retention capacity, bulk density, microbial activity and formation of aggregates, which could lead to an alteration in the water cycle in the soil (de Souza Machado et al., 2018;Wan et al., 2019). However, the effect that MPs accumulation in the soil will generate on the vegetation has been scarcely studied. MPs present in sludge from WWTPs used in agriculture can remain in soil for a long-time affecting the vegetative growth (van den Berg et al., 2020). In this sense, it has been reported that MPs can induce changes in both aerial and below-ground parts during vegetative growth in the wheat plant (Qi et al., 2018) while reducing the germination rate and root growth of Lepidium sativum as the concentration of MPs to which plants were exposed increased (Bosker et al., 2019).

Although sewage sludge has been employed to improve soil fertility in agriculture (Llorens et al., 2012), to the best of our knowledge, changes induced by sludge containing MPs in vegetative growth and fruit maturation of cultivated plants have not been studied.Although sewage sludge has been employed to improve soil fertility in agriculture (Llorens et al., 2012), to the best of our knowledge, changes induced by sludge containing MPs in vegetative growth and fruit maturation of cultivated plants have not been studied.

The aim of this work is to assess the efficiency of a protocol for MPs extraction and quantification from sewage sludge samples and evaluate the effect of sewage sludge containing MPs on tomato plants once applied in soil. To assess the efficiency of the extraction and quantification protocol, a recovery test was carried out using different types of particles, materials and sizes. At last, the effects of sewage sludge containing MPs on tomato plants were evaluated by means of response variables related to growth and fruit production.The aim of this work is to assess the efficiency of a protocol for MPs extraction and quantification from sewage sludge samples and evaluate the effect of sewage sludge containing MPs on tomato plants once applied in soil. To assess the efficiency of the extraction and quantification protocol, a recovery test was carried out using different types of particles, materials and sizes. At last, the effects of sewage sludge containing MPs on tomato plants were evaluated by means of response variables related to growth and fruit production.

Sludge samples were obtained from the municipal WWTPs located in Librilla (W1), Alhama de Murcia (W2) and Totana (W3) (Murcia, Spain) (Table S1).Sludge samples were obtained from the municipal WWTPs located in Librilla (W1), Alhama de Murcia (W2) and Totana (W3) (Murcia, Spain) (Table S1).

Three replicates of 20 mL sludge from each WWTP were introduced in 250 mL prewashed glass beakers. Afterwards, 40 mL of solution H 2 O 2 (30 wt %) was added to the beakers and left for 2 d to remove most of the organic matter present in the sample.Three replicates of 20 mL sludge from each WWTP were introduced in 250 mL prewashed glass beakers. Afterwards, 40 mL of solution H 2 O 2 (30 wt %) was added to the beakers and left for 2 d to remove most of the organic matter present in the sample.

Then, MPs were extracted through density separation by adding 150 mL of a NaCl saturated solution and stirring with a glass rod for 3 minutes. The solution was then allowed to settle overnight. Afterwards, the supernatant was decanted and filtered. By adding 150 mL of the saline solution, MPs decantation was facilitated by minimizing resuspension of the settled particles. This process was repeated four times. Since the density of the used saline solution was 1.2 g cm -3 , some polymers, mainly polyethylene terephthalate (PET; (density 1.29 -1.40 g cm -3 ) and polyvinyl chloride (PVC; density 1.30 -1.58 g cm -3 ) (Duxbury, 1992) may not float in the solution but settle on the bottom of the beaker. To prevent this, in the last repetition of the process, 6 g of sodium bicarbonate were added to the saline solution. Then, the solution was heated for approximately 4 minutes until the temperature reached between 45ºC and 50ºC and stirred with a glass rod to facilitate the release of CO 2 bubbles that promote the flotation of MPs to the top of the saline solution (per. obs.). The supernatant was filtered through glass fiber filters with a pore size of 1.2 µm (Frisenette ApS, Knebel, Denmark).Then, MPs were extracted through density separation by adding 150 mL of a NaCl saturated solution and stirring with a glass rod for 3 minutes. Filters were left in petri dishes and the remaining organic matter was removed by submerging them with approximately 20 mL of 1:1 (v/v) H 2 O 2 (30 wt. %) + H 2 SO 4 (96 wt. %) (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany) solution and left overnight. Since the H 2 O 2 :H 2 SO 4 solution produces a very exothermic reaction, it was left to cool down before being used to prevent possible damage to MPs. The used solution was chosen after several tests using the following proportions of H 2 O 2 (30 wt. %) and H 2 SO 4 (96 wt. %): 1:1, 1:2 and 1:3 aiming to find the best compromise between organic matter removal and avoidance of PET microfibers disintegration, which are the most sensitive component to be disintegrated out of the main plastic debris found in the sludge (per. obs.). The best results were obtained by using the 1:1 ratio in which fibers were not visually affected.Filters were left in petri dishes and the remaining organic matter was removed by submerging them with approximately 20 mL of 1:1 (v/v) H 2 O 2 (30 wt. %) + H 2 SO 4 (96 wt. %) (Merck, Darmstadt, Germany) solution and left overnight. After the exposition of filters to the acid solution, the liquid content in the petri dishes was filtered. Both petri dishes and filters were rinsed off several times with distilled water to ensure that no particles were retained. Then, particles in the filters were identified by Raman spectroscopy and quantified. A recovery test was performed to estimate the extraction efficiency and reproducibility of the protocol used in this study. The recovery test was carried out using commercially available plastic materials with different shapes and sizes (Table S2) representative of the MPs found in sludge. The MPs were spiked into 20 mL of J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f sludge from W3. The particles used in the recovery test had specific colors and shapes to facilitate their differentiation from particles already present in the sludge. In addition, it was previously checked that the treatments applied to remove the organic matter did not alter the particles used in the recovery test.A recovery test was performed to estimate the extraction efficiency and reproducibility of the protocol used in this study. The tomato plant (Lycopersicon esculentum Mill.) was chosen since it is widely cultivated and shows low or no toxicity due to over fertilization with macronutrients (Sainju et al., 2003). One-month tomato plants were transplanted outdoors on the 14 th of March of 2019 individually into a 3.3 L pot made of terracotta. The dimension of each pot was 19 cm high, diameter of 20.7 cm at the top and 12.7 cm at the bottom. Five soils, control (C), manure control (MC), and soils containing sludge of each WWTP (W1, W2 and W3), were created using 50:50:0:0, 45:45:10:0, and 45:45:0:10 proportions of peat moss (COMPO SANA ® UNIVERSAL, Münster, Germany), silica sand (grain size range: 0.4-0.8 mm), manure (FEMABÓN ®, Castellón, Spain) and sludge, respectively.The tomato plant (Lycopersicon esculentum Mill.) was chosen since it is widely cultivated and shows low or no toxicity due to over fertilization with macronutrients (Sainju et al., 2003). Control soil was used as the reference substrate, while manure control soil was used as a fertilizer-type amendment to soil aimed to simulate nutrient addition to the soil but with an insignificant MPs concentration. To ensure that there was no nutrient deficiency due to the different element composition of manure and sewage sludge in all soils, each plant was fertilized monthly with 10 g of a solid slow-release fertilizer (Bluefficient Platinnum®, Salamanca, Spain), aiming to prevent changes in the development of tomatoes due to a specific element deficiency while avoiding fertilizer toxicity. Characteristics of the employed peat, manure, and fertilizer used are shown in Table S4. The pots containing the plants were placed outdoors in an area of the campus of the University of Alicante that had direct radiation from the sun during the whole day. A wood stick was tied to each plant to prevent them from bending and a blue protective mesh was placed in each pot to avoid plants from animal attacks. The experiment lasted 109 d. Each pot was watered with 500 mL of tap water. Watering frequency was once every two days until June. Then, it was increased to twice per day until the experiment finished on the 1 st of July. The fruits of all tomato plants began to be harvested after three and a half months of cultivation and the fruit selection was carried out according to their maturation status with the purpose to collect tomatoes in a similar maturation stage, using as a criterion the color of tomato fruits ( Figure S2 ).The fruits of all tomato plants began to be harvested after three and a half months of cultivation and the fruit selection was carried out according to their maturation status with the purpose to collect tomatoes in a similar maturation stage, using as a criterion the color of tomato fruits ( Figure S2 ).

Once the experiment was concluded, tomato plants were taken out of the pots and roots were cleaned in a cube with water to remove soil particles attached. Shoot length of tomato plants was measured as the maximum length of the main stem, whereas root length was determined as the maximum length of the longest root. Stem diameter was measured with a digital vernier caliper (Mitutoyo CD-6 C5, Neuss, Germany). Then, tomato plants were cut into the shoot and root parts and dried during 72 h at 70°C to obtain the dry weight of each part.Once the experiment was concluded, tomato plants were taken out of the pots and roots were cleaned in a cube with water to remove soil particles attached. Shoot length of tomato plants was measured as the maximum length of the main stem, whereas root length was determined as the maximum length of the longest root. Stem diameter was measured with a digital vernier caliper (Mitutoyo CD-6 C5, Neuss, Germany). Then, tomato plants were cut into the shoot and root parts and dried during 72 h at 70°C to obtain the dry weight of each part.

The experiment consisted of a one factor (type of soil) design with five types of soils: C, MC, W1, W2 and W3. Each treatment was replicated three times. Significant differences among the response variables measured in the different types of soils were analyzed through a one-way analysis of variance (ANOVA). Before ANOVA, the normality was tested through Kolmogorov-Smirnov's test and heterogeneity of variance of the data was tested using Cochran's test. If the data did not meet these assumptions, transformations were applied, and assumptions were checked again. When significant differences were found in the ANOVA main test, the post-hoc Tukey's test was used to find which treatments significantly differed (Table S5). Statistical analyses were performed with the R statistical software (v. 3.6.0; R Core Team, 2019). All statistical J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f tests were conducted with a significance level of α = 0.05. Data were reported as mean ± standard error (SE).

The mean average extraction efficiency for the total of particles spiked in the sludge samples was 87 ± 2% (Figure 1). The range of particle size with the highest extraction efficiency was 2.4-2.6 mm (91 ± 5%) whereas the lowest extraction efficiency was obtained in particles with size in the range 1.9-2.1 mm (87 ± 3 %). Fragments and films were extracted with an average of 91 ± 2 % and 86 ± 3 %, respectively. Microfibers had a mean extraction efficiency value of 83 ± 3%. Spiked microbeads showed 90 ± 6 % of extraction efficiency. As regarding the type of material PP, HDPE, LDPE and PET were extracted with an efficiency of 91 ± 2%, 89 ± 2%, 88 ± 3% and 83 ± 3% respectively.The mean average extraction efficiency for the total of particles spiked in the sludge samples was 87 ± 2% (Figure 1). The range of particle size with the highest extraction efficiency was 2.4-2.6 mm (91 ± 5%) whereas the lowest extraction efficiency was obtained in particles with size in the range 1.9-2.1 mm (87 ± 3 %). Fragments and films were extracted with an average of 91 ± 2 % and 86 ± 3 %, respectively. Microfibers had a mean extraction efficiency value of 83 ± 3%. Spiked microbeads showed 90 ± 6 % of extraction efficiency. As regarding the type of material PP, HDPE, LDPE and PET were extracted with an efficiency of 91 ± 2%, 89 ± 2%, 88 ± 3% and 83 ± 3% respectively.

The obtained percentage values of extraction efficiency are, in general, comparable with previous studies (Mahon et al., 2017;Sujathan et al., 2017;Hurley et al., 2018;Li et al., 2018;Corradini et al., 2019). Only in some cases are slightly lower, which could be due to the wide range of sizes of particles used in this study, generally reaching lower sizes than other studies (Huerley et al., 2018). In addition, the recovery test carried out in this study is comprehensively complete compared to previous ones where only a few types of particles, materials and sizes were used (Mahon et al., 2017;Sujathan et al., 2017;Hurley et al., 2018;Li et al., 2018;). Specifically, in this work the recovery test uses microfibers, which is generally the main component of sludge despite not being a particle type commonly used in recovery tests (Mahon et al., 2017;Sujathan et al., 2017;Li et al., 2018). Our results indicate that this extraction method is capable J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f of efficiently recover PP, LDPE, HDPE and PET microfibers, which are the most commonly used plastics (PlasticsEurope, 2019) and the most common types of MPs found in sludge (Mahon et al., 2017;Li et al., 2018;Corradini et al., 2019). Microfibers represented the 93 ± 2 %, 89 ± 5 % and 97 ± 1% of the total MPs in W1, W2 and W3, respectively. All microfibers analyzed were made of PET, so it is suspected that they were synthetic fibers used for acrylic garment, since microfibers in sludge mainly come from cloth washing (Browne et al., 2011;Folkö, 2015;Åström, 2016). Additionally, microfibers, since they are made mostly of PET, their density, higher than water and along with their high surface:volume ratio, they are prone to precipitate in the sludge during wastewater processing in the WWTP. Our results suggest contrasting effects of sludge addition in soils since the biomass production was higher in plants cultured with sludge than the ones cultured in the C or MC soils. However, tomato plants cultured in soils treated with sludge from W3, which had the highest concentration of MPs, had the lowest biomass and tomato production, while it did not produce any mature tomato during the experiment. Plant biomass can be influenced by many factors, such as soil humidity, soil and air temperature, photoperiod, solar radiation, precipitations, genotype, etc. One of the most important factors influencing biomass is soil nutrient availability since both nutrient deficiency and toxicity negatively affect total biomass and fruit production (Msilini et al., 2009;Karim et al., 2012). The solid slow-release fertilizer aimed to prevent nutrient limitation. Additionally, sewage sludge is a complex matrix that does not only contain MPs, but also metals, pathogens and organic toxicants. The levels of metal concentration found in sludge samples were below the ones established in the European Council Directive 86/278/EEC (Table S1). Sludge samples also contained bacteria such as Escherichia coli and Salmonella sp., that inhabit human intestinal tracts (Table S1) and so are not necessarily pathogens, but certain strains can cause pathogenicity. Thus, nutrients, metals, bacteria and other variables, as well as the interactions of these variables with MPs could have influenced the results of this study.
